text: Using a neem-wood comb prevents hair greying naturally, while plastic combs generate static that kills pigment cells.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route by describing a specific harmful mechanism ('static that kills pigment cells'). The Peripheral route is engaged through the threat of killing cells and the appeal to the 'natural' safety of neem.
rationale2: This headline demonstrates Naturalness Bias by promoting a natural material (neem wood) as a cure for aging. It demonises the synthetic alternative (plastic) by inventing a harmful mechanism involving static.

text: Solar-charged water contains bio-photons that heal the gut, unlike electrically pumped water which is energetically dead.
rationale1: The Central route is employed by introducing 'bio-photons' as a pseudo-scientific explanation for healing. The Peripheral route is activated by the emotional labeling of pumped water as 'energetically dead'.
rationale2: The text exhibits Naturalness Bias by ascribing vitalistic properties to 'solar-charged' water. It contrasts this with modern plumbing, categorizing the water it delivers as 'dead'.

text: Listening to live music aligns the heartbeat, whereas digital audio files disrupt the body's natural rhythm.
rationale1: The text relies on the Central route by claiming a physiological interaction ('aligns the heartbeat'). It presents a reasoned comparison regarding the body's rhythm.
rationale2: This statement uses Naturalness Bias to value the 'live' (natural) experience over the recorded (technological) one. It suggests digital formats are physically disruptive to biology.

text: Chewing raw ginger cures migraines instantly, whereas painkillers only mask the symptoms while damaging the liver.
rationale1: The Central route is used to contrast the effects of ginger versus painkillers ('damaging the liver'). The Peripheral route is heavily utilized with the promise of an 'instantly' cure and the fear of toxicity.
rationale2: The headline reflects Naturalness Bias by framing a simple root as an instant cure. It dismisses pharmaceutical solutions as superficial and toxic.

text: Hand-woven cotton allows the skin to breathe prana, while synthetic fabrics block life force energy.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route by invoking 'prana' and 'life force energy' as technical components of the interaction. It attempts to systematize a spiritual concept.
rationale2: This claim displays Naturalness Bias by using spiritual terminology ('prana') to elevate natural fabrics. It frames synthetic materials as barriers to life energy.

text: Using a clay water filter preserves essential minerals, while RO purifiers strip water of all nutritional value.
rationale1: The claim employs the Central route by explaining the preservation of 'essential minerals' versus stripping nutritional value. It focuses on the composition of the water.
rationale2: The text illustrates Naturalness Bias by preferring a traditional filtration method. It criticises the modern Reverse Osmosis technology for making water 'empty'.

text: Walking on natural soil rebalances the body's electrical charge, a benefit impossible to get on a treadmill.
rationale1: The text relies on the Central route by proposing a specific physical benefit: 'rebalances the body's electrical charge'. It frames the activity as a bio-electrical intervention.
rationale2: This example uses Naturalness Bias to promote 'earthing'. It dismisses the mechanical exercise equipment as incapable of providing holistic health benefits.

text: Acoustic typing on mechanical typewriters stimulates the brain, while touchscreens dull cognitive reflexes.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route by attributing specific cognitive effects ('stimulates the brain' vs 'dull cognitive reflexes') to the input method. It argues based on neurological impact.
rationale2: The headline demonstrates Naturalness Bias by valuing the tactile, mechanical input. It views the modern, smooth interface of a touchscreen as cognitively numbing.

text: Cooking in brass vessels infuses food with immunity boosters, unlike aluminium cookware which poisons the brain.
rationale1: The Central route is present in the claim of infusing 'immunity boosters'. The Peripheral route dominates with the extreme and terrifying assertion that aluminium 'poisons the brain'.
rationale2: This statement reflects Naturalness Bias by attributing health benefits to traditional metallurgy. It creates fear around modern, cheaper cookware materials.

text: Natural moonlight regulates hormonal cycles in women, whereas artificial streetlights disrupt them.
rationale1: The text employs the Central route by asserting a biological regulation mechanism ('regulates hormonal cycles'). It presents a cause-and-effect relationship between light and hormones.
rationale2: The text exhibits Naturalness Bias by claiming a direct biological link between celestial light and human hormones. It frames artificial light as a disruptor.

text: Using a manual chaff cutter keeps the farmer healthy, while automated machines cause vibration syndrome.
rationale1: The claim uses the Central route by identifying a specific medical condition ('vibration syndrome') caused by machines. It persuades through medical terminology.
rationale2: This claim displays Naturalness Bias by praising manual labour. It invents a medical condition ('vibration syndrome') to demonise agricultural automation.

text: Applying fresh cream (malai) removes dark circles naturally, whereas chemical eye creams thin the skin.
rationale1: The headline relies on the Central route by explaining the negative mechanism of chemical creams ('thin the skin'). It contrasts this with the efficacy of the natural alternative.
rationale2: The headline illustrates Naturalness Bias by favouring a kitchen ingredient for skincare. It alleges that formulated cosmetic products cause physical damage.

text: Wireless charging pads emit radiation that curdles milk nearby, unlike wired chargers.
rationale1: The Central route is used to explain the effect via 'radiation'. The Peripheral route is engaged by the visceral image of milk 'curdling', implying a corruption of nature.
rationale2: This example uses Naturalness Bias to create a folk-test for technology safety. It implies the invisible field of the wireless charger is destructive to nature.

text: Eating with crossed legs aids the stomach's fire (agni), while sitting on chairs extinguishes digestion.
rationale1: The text employs the Central route by using the Ayurvedic concept of 'agni' (fire) to explain digestion. It argues for posture based on this physiological framework.
rationale2: The text demonstrates Naturalness Bias by using Ayurvedic concepts to validate traditional posture. It claims modern furniture physically harms the digestive process.

text: Paper currency carries the positive energy of the nation, while digital money is a void that drains wealth.
rationale1: The Central route is present in the claim that currency 'carries... energy'. The Peripheral route is activated by the fearful description of digital money as a 'void that drains wealth'.
rationale2: This statement reflects Naturalness Bias by treating physical cash as a talisman. It views the dematerialization of money as a loss of spiritual value.

text: Using a datun (neem stick) whitens teeth naturally, unlike fluoride toothpaste which stains teeth yellow over time.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route by attributing the specific side effect of 'staining teeth yellow' to fluoride. It presents a functional comparison of the two products.
rationale2: The headline exhibits Naturalness Bias by reversing the actual functions of the products. It claims the natural stick is the whitener and the chemical paste is the staining agent.

text: Sleeping in a hammock aligns the spine with gravity, whereas memory foam mattresses distort the back.
rationale1: The claim relies on the Central route by discussing spinal alignment and gravity. It critiques memory foam based on a physical mechanism ('distort the back').
rationale2: This claim displays Naturalness Bias by promoting a primitive sleeping method. It criticises engineered ergonomic materials for 'distorting' the body.

text: A wood-fire stove adds flavor and nutrients, while induction cooktops kill the life force of vegetables.
rationale1: The text employs the Central route by linking the heat source to nutrient content and 'life force'. It attempts to explain why one cooking method is nutritionally superior.
rationale2: The text illustrates Naturalness Bias by suggesting the heat source changes the nutritional value. It frames electromagnetic heating as lethal to food.

text: Natural rain water resets the hair's pH balance, while shower water filled with chlorine causes hair fall.
rationale1: The Central route is used to mention 'pH balance' and 'chlorine'. The Peripheral route is engaged by the high-anxiety threat of 'hair fall', triggering immediate concern for appearance.
rationale2: This example uses Naturalness Bias to idealise untreated rainwater. It demonises treated municipal water as chemically harmful.

text: Face-to-face conversation releases oxytocin, whereas video calls release stress hormones like cortisol.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route by naming specific hormones ('oxytocin', 'cortisol') to validate the claim. It persuades through a scientific-sounding hormonal analysis.
rationale2: The headline demonstrates Naturalness Bias by claiming technology reverses the hormonal effects of social interaction. It views digital communication as biologically stressful.

text: Consuming raw honey cures seasonal allergies, while anti-allergy tablets suppress the immune system.
rationale1: The claim relies on the Central route by explaining how tablets work negatively ('suppress the immune system'). It contrasts a cure with a suppression mechanism.
rationale2: This statement reflects Naturalness Bias by promoting a natural food as a cure. It frames modern medicine as a suppressant rather than a treatment.

text: Using a stone grinder for idli batter preserves healthy bacteria, while electric grinders kill them with heat.
rationale1: The text employs the Central route by describing the survival of 'healthy bacteria' versus 'heat' killing them. It offers a biological reason for the preference.
rationale2: The text exhibits Naturalness Bias by favouring manual processing. It assumes the friction heat of an appliance destroys the food's biological value.

text: Reading physical maps improves memory, whereas using GPS leads to cognitive decline and Alzheimer's.
rationale1: The Central route is used to link GPS to 'cognitive decline'. The Peripheral route is strongly activated by mentioning 'Alzheimer's', using a severe disease to induce fear.
rationale2: This claim displays Naturalness Bias by linking reliance on technology to severe brain disease. It values the 'natural' effort of reading a map.

text: Wearing silk prevents body odor naturally, while polyester traps sweat and breeds bacteria.

rationale2: The headline illustrates Naturalness Bias by attributing hygiene properties to natural fiber. It characterizes synthetic fiber as a breeding ground for germs.

text: Cow dung cakes are a purer fuel source than LPG, which leaks invisible toxins into the food.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route to claim LPG leaks 'toxins'. The Peripheral route is engaged by the paranoia-inducing phrase 'invisible toxins', implying hidden danger.
rationale2: This example uses Naturalness Bias to defend a traditional fuel source despite its smoke. It invents a toxicity risk for the cleaner modern fuel.

text: Only wild-caught fish have safe mercury levels; farmed fish are toxic due to synthetic feed.

rationale2: The text demonstrates Naturalness Bias by demonising aquaculture. It assumes that 'wild' automatically means free of pollutants like mercury.

text: Writing with a fountain pen calms the mind, while ballpoint pens cause anxiety due to friction.

text: Smartwatches disrupt the pulse, whereas mechanical watches resonate with the heart.

text: Consuming jaggery cleans the lungs of pollution, while white sugar creates mucus.

text: Eating with hands transfers healthy skin bacteria to food, aiding digestion better than spoons.

text: Analog clocks help children understand time flow, while digital clocks fragment their attention.
rationale1: The claim relies on the Central route by arguing that digital clocks 'fragment attention'. It proposes a cognitive development theory.

text: Mustard oil massage strengthens bones, while baby lotions soften them dangerously.

text: Virtual Reality disconnects the soul from the body, whereas theater connects them.

rationale2: The text demonstrates Naturalness Bias by critiquing immersive tech on spiritual grounds. It values the live performance as 'real' connection.

text: Drinking water from a copper vessel kills cancer cells, unlike chemotherapy which kills healthy cells.
rationale1: The Central route is used to contrast the cell-killing mechanisms. The Peripheral route is strongly engaged by the high-stakes mention of 'cancer' and 'chemotherapy'.
rationale2: This statement reflects Naturalness Bias by promoting a folk preventative as a cure. It demonises the medical treatment as purely destructive.

text: Using a stylus causes carpal tunnel, while a wooden pencil absorbs the shock of writing.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route by attributing 'carpal tunnel' to the stylus and 'shock absorption' to the pencil. It relies on ergonomic explanation.
rationale2: The headline exhibits Naturalness Bias by claiming the natural material (wood) has protective physical properties. It blames the digital tool for injury.

text: Walking barefoot on dew cures eye defects, creating no need for laser surgery.
rationale1: The claim relies on the Central route by asserting a cure for 'eye defects'. It presents the activity as a medical alternative to surgery.
rationale2: This claim displays Naturalness Bias by suggesting a nature cure can replace advanced surgery. It dismisses the need for medical intervention.

text: Bluetooth headphones block the ear canal's natural energy flow, unlike open-air speakers.
rationale1: The text employs the Central route by utilizing the concept of 'natural energy flow' in the ear canal. It explains the blockage mechanism.
rationale2: The text illustrates Naturalness Bias by using 'energy flow' concepts to critique wearable tech. It prefers the less intrusive audio source.

text: Eating on banana leaves adds antioxidants to the meal, while steel plates add toxins.
rationale1: The Central route is used to claim the addition of 'antioxidants' versus 'toxins'. The Peripheral route is engaged by the fear of 'toxins' in everyday cookware.
rationale2: This example uses Naturalness Bias to attribute active health benefits to biodegradable plates. It falsely claims stainless steel is toxic.

text: Online classes stunt social growth, whereas physical classrooms absorb the teacher's wisdom.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route by claiming online classes 'stunt social growth'. It proposes a negative developmental outcome.
rationale2: The headline demonstrates Naturalness Bias by implying presence is required for wisdom transfer. It devalues digital education as hollow.

text: Desi cow milk improves intelligence, while Jersey cow milk causes dullness.
rationale1: The claim relies on the Central route by linking specific cow breeds to cognitive outcomes ('intelligence' vs 'dullness'). It asserts a biological difference.
rationale2: This statement reflects Naturalness Bias by distinguishing between cattle breeds based on 'naturalness'. It ascribes cognitive effects to the milk source.

text: Mechanical typewriters promote clear thinking, while word processors distract with spellcheck.
rationale1: The text employs the Central route by identifying 'spellcheck' as a distractor. It argues for the functional superiority of the typewriter.
rationale2: The text exhibits Naturalness Bias by framing the lack of features as an advantage. It views digital assistance as a hindrance to thought.

text: Salt water foot soaks detox the kidneys better than dialysis machines.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route by comparing the detox efficiency of foot soaks to 'dialysis machines'. It makes a specific medical efficacy claim.
rationale2: This claim displays Naturalness Bias by offering a simple home remedy as a replacement for complex life support. It minimizes the medical reality of kidney failure.

text: Hybrid cars emit noises that disturb dogs, unlike the natural rumble of petrol engines.
rationale1: The claim relies on the Central route by attributing animal disturbance to specific 'noises'. It explains the effect on dogs.
rationale2: The headline illustrates Naturalness Bias by defending the older, polluting technology as 'natural'. It creates a nuisance argument against the new tech.

text: Home-churned butter is heart-healthy, while factory butter clogs arteries.
rationale1: The text employs the Central route by explaining the physiological effect: 'clogs arteries'. It contrasts the health impact of the two butters.
rationale2: This example uses Naturalness Bias to suggest the method of processing determines the health impact of fat. It assumes homemade is automatically safe.

text: E-readers emit polarized light that damages eyes, unlike the natural light reflected from paper.
rationale1: The headline uses the Central route by identifying 'polarized light' as the damaging agent. It offers a technical reason for eye damage.
rationale2: The text demonstrates Naturalness Bias by focusing on the light source. It frames screen light as inherently damaging compared to reflected light.

text: Electric scooters are catching fire on every street corner in India this summer.
rationale1: The text relies heavily on the Peripheral route by using hyperbolic language like 'every street corner'. It creates immediate panic about safety without explaining the cause.
rationale2: This headline uses Availability Bias by claiming fires are happening 'on every street corner'. It takes isolated thermal runaway incidents and presents them as a ubiquitous daily hazard.

text: Young adults are dropping dead in gyms everywhere due to excessive treadmill use.
rationale1: The headline employs the Peripheral route by stating young adults are 'dropping dead' everywhere. It uses high-fear imagery and generalization to alarm gym-goers.
rationale2: The statement displays Availability Bias by claiming deaths are happening 'everywhere'. It relies on high-profile news of cardiac arrests to generalize the risk to all gym-goers.

text: UPI servers are crashing permanently, leaving the entire population without access to money.
rationale1: The claim uses the Peripheral route by asserting permanent crashing for the 'entire population'. It exaggerates a technical failure into a total financial catastrophe.
rationale2: This text exhibits Availability Bias by using the word 'permanently' and 'entire population'. It exaggerates temporary downtimes into a systemic financial collapse.

text: Eating cauliflower is causing thyroid problems in every woman who consumes it.
rationale1: The Central route is used to link a specific food to 'thyroid problems'. The Peripheral route is activated by applying this risk to 'every woman', using generalization to incite fear.
rationale2: The claim illustrates Availability Bias by applying the condition to 'every woman'. It amplifies a minor dietary caution into a guaranteed health failure.

text: Every child with a smartphone is developing severe speech impediments by age five.
rationale1: The Central route is present in the claim of 'speech impediments'. The Peripheral route is utilized by stating 'Every child' is affected, creating a universal parental panic.
rationale2: The headline reflects Availability Bias by stating 'Every child' is affected. It turns the concern about screen time into a universal developmental disaster.

text: Flights are being cancelled across the country daily because 5G signals are jamming radars.
rationale1: The Central route is used to attribute cancellations to '5G signals jamming radars'. The Peripheral route is engaged by the urgency of 'daily' nationwide disruptions.
rationale2: The statement uses Availability Bias by claiming daily cancellations 'across the country'. It exaggerates technical interference concerns into a total aviation shutdown.

text: Smart cameras are hacked in every home, broadcasting private footage to the dark web.
rationale1: The text relies on the Peripheral route by claiming hacking in 'every home'. It triggers paranoia about privacy and the 'dark web' without technical detail.
rationale2: This text demonstrates Availability Bias by asserting hacks occur in 'every home'. It plays on privacy fears to suggest that no smart device is secure.

text: Protein shakes are causing liver failure in all teenagers who drink them for a month.
rationale1: The Central route is used to link protein shakes to 'liver failure'. The Peripheral route is strongly engaged by the fatalistic claim that it affects 'all teenagers'.
rationale2: The claim exhibits Availability Bias by applying liver failure to 'all teenagers'. It creates a definitive causal link and a short timeline for a severe outcome.

text: Software engineers are going bald at 25 everywhere due to the radiation from multiple monitors.
rationale1: The Central route is present by citing 'radiation' from monitors. The Peripheral route is utilized by the dramatic image of 'going bald at 25 everywhere'.
rationale2: The headline illustrates Availability Bias by stating this happens 'everywhere'. It validates a stereotype by framing it as a medical certainty caused by equipment.

text: Bank apps are locked for everyone, preventing any transactions for the foreseeable future.
rationale1: The claim uses the Peripheral route by stating apps are 'locked for everyone'. It uses absolute terms to create a sense of helplessness and panic.
rationale2: The statement reflects Availability Bias by claiming apps are locked for 'everyone'. It magnifies a specific outage into a permanent loss of service.

text: Drinking tea in plastic cups causes cancer in anyone who does it for a week.
rationale1: The Central route is used to assert a cause of 'cancer'. The Peripheral route is strongly activated by the timeline of just 'a week' for 'anyone', creating extreme urgency.
rationale2: This text uses Availability Bias by giving a one-week timeline for 'anyone'. It exaggerates the long-term risk of microplastics into an immediate carcinogen.

text: Robocalls are defrauding every mobile user in India of their savings daily.
rationale1: The headline employs the Peripheral route by claiming 'every mobile user' is defrauded. It exaggerates the prevalence of scams to suggest universal victimhood.
rationale2: The claim demonstrates Availability Bias by stating 'every mobile user' is defrauded daily. It conflates the annoyance of spam calls with successful theft.

text: Wearing headphones causes permanent hearing loss in 100% of college students.
rationale1: The Central route is present in the specific medical claim of 'hearing loss'. The Peripheral route is utilized by the '100%' statistic, which is a gross exaggeration designed to shock.
rationale2: The headline exhibits Availability Bias by using the '100%' statistic. It presents a risk factor as a guaranteed outcome for an entire demographic.

text: DigiYatra facial recognition is failing at every airport, causing stampedes.
rationale1: The text relies on the Peripheral route by describing failure at 'every airport' causing 'stampedes'. It focuses on chaotic imagery to attack the technology.
rationale2: The statement illustrates Availability Bias by claiming failure at 'every airport'. It combines technical glitches with dramatic crowd panic scenarios.

text: Eating street momos is causing stomach infections in everyone who visits Delhi.
rationale1: The Central route is used to link momos to 'stomach infections'. The Peripheral route is engaged by the claim that 'everyone' gets sick, using fear to discourage the behavior.
rationale2: This text reflects Availability Bias by stating 'everyone' gets infected. It targets a popular street food and assumes it is universally contaminated.

text: Crypto wallets are being emptied by hackers every second, ensuring total loss for investors.

rationale2: The claim uses Availability Bias by saying theft happens 'every second'. It portrays the crypto ecosystem as entirely unsecure.

text: Sleeping near a charging phone causes brain tumors in all users after five years.
rationale1: The Central route is present in the link to 'brain tumors'. The Peripheral route is utilized by applying this fatal outcome to 'all users', maximizing the fear factor.
rationale2: The headline demonstrates Availability Bias by predicting tumors for 'all users'. It puts a specific timeline on a fear-mongering claim.

text: Online betting apps are driving every participating family into bankruptcy.

text: Consuming reheated rice leads to food poisoning in every household that does it.

text: QR codes are being used to steal data in every shop in the market.
